author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: 50 Years Later, Some Question Value of U.S.-China ‘Panda Diplomacy’
description: In 1972, China sent two pandas to the United States as a gesture of good will. In recent years, experts say the animals have taken on a new role: softening China’s authoritarian image.
content: Fifty years ago this month, Chairman Mao made President Richard M. Nixon a promise: He would send two giant pandas to the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Morning Waker-Upper
description: Alan Siegel’s debut is a one-stop shop for all your puzzling needs.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to the constructor Alan Siegel, who is making his New York Times Crossword debut today with this all-inclusive puzzle. I’m always interested to hear constructor origin stories, and I love that Mr. Siegel’s story begins with a lecture by David Steinberg, then a high school student and now a nationally syndicated puzzle editor.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘We Retreated to a Nearby Shop to Discuss Our Options Over Coffee’
description: Overheard at a SoHo deli, a surprising encounter at Bloomingdale’s and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Teaching Black History Month, Under New Limits
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, February 13, 2022.
content: “I am not going to let any of these laws deter me from the things that I think work best for students. But I also enjoy working with students and having a roof over my head.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiya Miles
title: In Anxious Times, Black History Can Be a Blueprint for Survival
description: It is not a viable strategy to close our minds against the threat by believing all is already lost.
content: It was a regular January evening in a household like many others, in which three kids would be going to school (or not) the next day, depending on the latest vicissitudes of the Omicron variant of Covid-19. Around the dinner table, my husband, kids and I were assessing the school situation and calibrating our response. New cases in the high school that our twins attend had hit alarming double digits. At the middle school that our youngest attends cases were not very far behind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas and Ana Ionova
title: Brazil’s Joe Rogan Faces His Own Firestorm Over Free Speech
description: Bruno Aiub became one of Brazil’s biggest podcasters with irreverent interviews of newsmakers. Now remarks about Nazis plunged him into a controversy akin to his idol’s.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — He is perhaps the nation’s most popular podcaster. He broadcasts hourslong interviews, often with divisive newsmakers. He sometimes gets high with his guests. And he is now in the middle of a firestorm over his comments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper and Gabriela Bhaskar
title: Erin Jackson Wins Gold in Speedskating, a First Several Times Over
description: Jackson’s gold was the first medal for a U.S. speedskater in Beijing and made her the first African American to medal in her sport.
content: BEIJING — Erin Jackson ended a drought of U.S. speedskating medals by taking first place in the women’s 500-meter race on Sunday, becoming the first African American woman to win a medal in the sport. It is also the first medal for an American speedskater in Beijing and the first individual speedskating medal won by an American since the 2010 Vancouver Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: In Miami, a ‘Swan Lake’ That Blasts Off the Cobwebs
description: Miami City Ballet’s production of Alexei Ratmansky’s enthralling “Swan Lake” brings a beloved work into crisp, clean and musical focus.
content: MIAMI — The swans make all the difference.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: The giant slalom winner navigates an unexpected rival: fresh powder.
description: Marco Odermatt of Switzerland, the world’s top giant slalom skier, earned his first gold medal.
content: Marco Odermatt of Switzerland, the world’s top giant slalom skier, won the event at the Beijing Olympics on Sunday, navigating an unusual — and perhaps unwelcome — coating of fresh powder to earn his first gold medal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: He Knows Putin Well. And He Fears for Ukraine.
description: The Finnish president, Sauli Niinisto, has carved out a vital role as interpreter between East and West, and he is not optimistic about the prospects for peace.
content: HELSINKI — As the threat of a new Russian invasion of Ukraine grew, the European head of state with the longest and deepest experience dealing with Vladimir V. Putin fielded calls and doled out advice to President Emmanuel Macron of France and other world leaders desperate for insight into his difficult neighbor to the east.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bhadra Sharma
title: Nepal’s Chief Justice Is Suspended, Deepening Political Chaos
description: Accusations and a possible ouster could aggravate divisions that have paralyzed much of the Nepal government for months.
content: KATHMANDU, Nepal — The chief justice of Nepal’s Supreme Court was suspended on Sunday after lawmakers voted to impeach him on accusations that he removed the former prime minister and reinstated Parliament in exchange for political jobs for relatives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Weather pushes slopestyle qualifiers to Monday.
description: Eileen Gu will be competing in hopes of winning her second gold medal.
content: ZHANGJIAKOU, China — Snow and wind pushed Sunday’s slopestyle qualifiers to Monday, delaying the medal hopes of China’s favorite Olympic athlete — the 18-year-old freestyle skier Eileen Gu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Audra D. S. Burch
title: In Arbery Hate Crimes Trial, Racism Will Take Center Stage
description: Jurors in the unusual case will be asked to decide if the men who chased and killed Ahmaud Arbery were motivated by racial animus. The evidence they may consider includes explicitly racist language.
content: ATLANTA — The killing of George Floyd catalyzed a period of national soul-searching about race and racism that has touched nearly every aspect of American life. But in a number of high-profile trials since then — including in the murder of Mr. Floyd and the killing of Ahmaud Arbery — prosecutors have carefully avoided putting racism itself on center stage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: As women’s hockey advances to the semifinals, a fierce rivalry comes into focus.
description: The semifinal of a major sports tournament is bound to bring excitement, as top contenders battle it out with a trip to the final on the line.
content: The semifinal of a major sports tournament is bound to bring excitement, as top contenders battle it out with a trip to the final on the line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Stulberg
title: You’ve Done Self Care. You’ve Languished. Now Try This.
description: As with just about everything related to Covid, we’re sick of languishing, too.
content: In our first session this year, my coaching client Jane told me that she has rested, given herself permission to feel down, and lowered her personal bar, just as we all have been advised to do as we wearily approach the third year of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Feb. 14, 2022
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Maggie Haberman, Michael S. Schmidt and Luke Broadwater
title: Giuliani in Talks to Testify to House Jan. 6 Panel
description: It is not clear how much assistance he might provide in the investigation into former President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to hold onto power.
content: Rudolph W. Giuliani, who as former President Donald J. Trump’s lawyer helped lead the effort to overturn the results of the 2020 election, is in discussions with the House Jan. 6 committee about responding to its questions, according to three people familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: In Hawaii, Blinken Aims for a United Front With Allies on North Korea
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and his counterparts from South Korea and Japan denounced the North’s recent missile tests and called for a resumption of talks.
content: HONOLULU — Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and the foreign ministers of South Korea and Japan on Saturday presented a unified front against North Korea’s recent missile tests, which the country has been conducting at its fastest rate in years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Kodak Black Is Shot in Los Angeles
description: The rapper, whose legal name is Bill Kapri, was shot in the leg while assisting another person after an “unprovoked attack,” his lawyer said.
content: The rapper Kodak Black was among four people shot outside a party in Los Angeles early Saturday after what his lawyer said was an “unprovoked attack” on a person he was with at the time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Crouse
title: Why the Beijing Olympics Are So Hard to Watch
description: Instead of showing the best of what humanity can do, this year’s Olympics seem to reflect what we can’t.
content: Imagine a dystopian Olympics. Maybe it would have athletes skiing on fake snow down parched slopes. Robots mixing cocktails, making dumplings and disinfecting the air. Events staffed by workers not in sportswear but hazmat suits. Instead of a stadium you are eager to get a seat in, a bubble you cannot leave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Israel Adesanya Extends U.F.C. Reign, and the Money Follows
description: With a new contract in hand, Israel Adesanya outclassed Robert Whittaker in U.F.C. 271. It was his fourth successful defense of the title he won from Whittaker in 2019.
content: After successfully defending his Ultimate Fighting Championship middleweight title in Houston on Saturday night, Israel Adesanya arrived at the post-fight news conference ready to analyze how he had outclassed Robert Whittaker for a second time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Trial of Ex-Goldman Banker Involved in 1MDB Scandal Set to Begin
description: Roger Ng was indicted in 2018 for his role in the looting of Malaysia’s government fund. His trial starts Monday.
content: The global scandal over the looting of a big Malaysian infrastructure fund nearly a decade ago — a crime that tarnished the reputation of one of Wall Street’s premier banks — is about to play out once again in a federal courthouse in Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron E. Carroll
title: Covid Drugs May Work Well, but Our Health System Doesn’t
description: The people who need treatments the most may be the least likely to get them.
content: Vaccines are essential for creating widespread immunity against the coronavirus. But drugs that can treat Covid-19 are also critical to combat the pandemic. This is especially true for places where large numbers of people remain unvaccinated and unboosted. These individuals could benefit from treatment if they get sick. Others, like the immunocompromised, may need additional help to fight off the disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: An Omicron wave prompts Hong Kong to halt its policy of hospitalizing all virus cases.
description: The city recorded eight Covid deaths last week, the first since September.
content: HONG KONG — The Hong Kong government said on Sunday that it would begin prioritizing hospital isolation space for children, older people and other serious cases as a wave of coronavirus infections has swamped health care resources in the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $600,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins and Benjamin Weiser
title: Inside the Bitcoin Laundering Case That Confounded the Internet
description: The arrests of Ilya Lichtenstein and Heather Morgan left the world of cryptocurrency incredulous: Could this goofy young couple have been Bitcoin’s Bonnie and Clyde?
content: When anonymous hackers infiltrated the cryptocurrency exchange Bitfinex in 2016, it shook the nascent world of digital currency and prompted speculation about who might have stolen what was then $71 million in Bitcoin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: Inglewood Has Experienced Dramatic Change. The Super Bowl Is Proof of That.
description: With a glittering N.F.L. stadium and a new N.B.A. arena on the way, the city of Inglewood, Calif., is celebrating its progress. But on the streets, stark disparities linger.
content: [Follow the Super Bowl live with Joe Burrow, Odell Beckham Jr, Matthew Stafford and Aaron Donald.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Carmen Herrera, Cuban-Born Artist Who Won Fame at 89, Dies at 106
description: She painted in obscurity for decades, living on the earnings of her husband, an English teacher. Everything changed with a gallery show in 2004.
content: Carmen Herrera, a Cuban-born artist who painted abstract geometric shapes in Paris and New York all but unnoticed for most of her long life, then soared to international fame after her canvases began selling when she was 89, died on Saturday at the loft in Lower Manhattan that had been her home for 60 years.  She was 106.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Hoppert
title: SoFi Stadium sits on land with a history of glamour, for both humans and horses.
description: The Super Bowl will be held on the same ground where Seabiscuit once galloped and Hollywood’s elite mingled.
content: Plenty of celebrities will converge on SoFi Stadium in Inglewood, Calif., when the Rams and the Bengals meet in the Super Bowl on Sunday. And while the stadium is only two years old, the site is certainly no stranger to glamour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Sigal Barsade, 56, Dies; Argued That It’s OK to Show Emotions at Work
description: Her pioneering research showed that feelings have a place in the office, and that good leaders should learn to embrace that fact.
content: Sigal Barsade, whose studies of organizational culture charted the internal dynamics of the American workplace as precisely as any episode of “The Office,” and who advised countless companies on how to embrace and nurture their employees’ emotional well-being, died on Feb. 6 at her home in Wynnewood, Pa. She was 56.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Before a Disputed Drug Test, a Russian Figure Skater Had a Rapid Rise
description: Kamila Valieva, the teenager who tested positive for a banned substance, throwing her sport in disarray at the Olympics, likes stuffed animals and yearns to travel. And she has stunned seasoned veterans with her grace and athleticism.
content: Update: Arbitrators ruled that Kamila Valieva can continue to compete in the Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Kamila Valieva’s arbitration hearing is over. Here’s what comes next.
description: The hearing will determine if the Russian figure skater who failed a pre-Olympics doping test will be able to continue to compete at the Beijing Games.
content: Update: Arbitrators ruled that Kamila Valieva can continue to compete in the Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: The Week in Business: Peloton’s Tough Times
description: Prices continued their steep upward trajectory in January, merger plans hit roadblocks and mask mandates are being lifted.
content: Early in the pandemic, with gyms closed and people stuck at home, demand for Peloton’s bikes and virtual classes soared. So did its share price. But sales growth has slowed as gyms and fitness studios reopened. The company’s outlook has not been helped by a recall of its treadmills over safety concerns and fictional characters suffering heart attacks while riding its bikes in not just one, but two popular television shows. Peloton has been forced to hit the brakes, halting production of its bikes and treadmills, scratching plans for a new factory in Ohio and on Tuesday announcing that it would lay off 2,800 workers, about 20 percent of its work force. The company’s founder, John Foley, said he would step down as chief executive and become executive chairman. Barry McCarthy, a former chief financial officer of Spotify, was named chief executive and president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Review: An Audition Season Begins at the Philharmonic
description: Jakub Hrusa is the first of several guest conductors appearing with the orchestra in the coming weeks as it searches for its next music director.
content: It’s audition season at the New York Philharmonic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas
title: Some U.S. governors defend their mask policy changes to ‘get back to normal.’
description: The move by several states to lift restrictions comes as a new CBS poll found that a majority of Americans still support mask mandates, including in schools.
content: The governors of Maryland and New Jersey defended their moves to ease Covid restrictions, saying on Sunday that falling coronavirus cases in their states justified a change even as new cases and deaths remain fairly high in some regions of the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: After a reply on Instagram, Eileen Gu faces criticism over ‘special treatment.’
description: Social media users criticized the Chinese American skier after she suggested they download tools to use the internet that are illegal for most Chinese citizens.
content: With one gold medal under her belt, Eileen Gu, the 18-year-old American-born Chinese skier, has become a superstar almost overnight in China, charming the country with her superior athletic skills, model looks and standout intellect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor, Rebecca Thomas, John Branch and Keith Bradsher
title: Olympic venues get real snow, a rarity.
description: Winter weather catches up to a Games that has relied on artificial snow.
content: After more than a week of competition on courses lined with machine-made snow, actual snow and high winds forced the postponement or cancellation of at least three Olympic events on Sunday as flurries blanketed courses and slippery roads made getting to them difficult.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Divorcing Couples Fight Over the Kids, the House and Now the Crypto
description: Dividing the family’s Bitcoin stash has become a major source of contention in divorce cases.
content: The divorce dragged on for eight years, almost as long as the marriage. The wealthy San Francisco couple sparred over child support, the profits from the sale of the husband’s software company and the fate of their $3.6 million home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Brinkhurst-Cuff and Miya Lee
title: We Asked: What Is Black Love Today?
description: A new collaboration between Modern Love and the Black History, Continued project showcases the voices of writers, thinkers, journalists and readers to answer that question.
content: Charlie Brinkhurst-Cuff is a senior staff editor focusing on Black History, Continued. Miya Lee is the Modern Love projects editor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noele Illien
title: Swiss Approve Ban on Tobacco Ads
description: Health advocates have said that the legislation, which was approved in a referendum, was a significant step toward tightening the country’s loose tobacco regulations.
content: ZURICH — Advertisements glamorizing cigarettes will soon be a thing of the past in Switzerland, after voters on Sunday overwhelmingly approved legislation forbidding tobacco companies from displaying them in public spaces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Precious Fondren and Ashley Southall
title: Woman Followed and Fatally Stabbed in Her Chinatown Apartment
description: Christina Yuna Lee was a creative producer at a digital music platform. The 25-year-old man arrested in her killing had a record of misdemeanor arrests.
content: A 35-year-old woman was stabbed to death inside her Lower Manhattan apartment early Sunday by a man who had followed her from the street and into her building, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: He Loves Snowboarding. He Also Wants to Change It.
description: Chris Corning is hoping to land on the podium next week after narrowly missing an Olympic medal four years ago. His long-term ambitions for his sport may be just as difficult to achieve.
content: The Olympic snowboarder Chris Corning is a dutiful conformist in a sport renowned for its proud legacy of nonconformity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: An 8-Year-Old Street Child Is Killed, and a World Opens Up
description: In “Walking the Bowl,” Chris Lockhart and Daniel Mulilo Chama stumble upon a real-life murder mystery in a dump in Zambia.
content: WALKING THE BOWL A True Story of Murder and Survival Among the Street Children of Lusaka By Chris Lockhart and Daniel Mulilo Chama
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: The Jarring Run of the World’s Most Decorated Bobsledder
description: Kaillie Humphries won two Olympic golds for Canada, but after accusing her coach of abuse, she sought a fresh start. It has come with the United States.
content: Update: Kaillie Humphries took gold in the Monobob in Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Good Riddance to Good Taste
description: Shayne Oliver returns, and Eckhaus Latta celebrates a decade. New York fashion is on the move.
content: It’s been a while since a New York Fashion Week show was an hour late and almost no one cared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Aida Alami
title: The Quiet Flight of Muslims From France
description: All the talk of France’s presidential election campaign is about immigration. But it is the expanding emigration of French Muslims that points to a deeper crisis for the country.
content: PARIS — France’s wounded psyche is the invisible character in every one of Sabri Louatah’s novels and the hit television series he wrote. He speaks of his “sensual, physical, visceral love” for the French language and of his attachment to his hometown in southeastern France, bathed in its distinctive light. He closely monitors the campaign for the upcoming presidential elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: There Will Be No Post-Covid
description: Covid is here to stay. So are the societal transformations it’s caused.
content: There have been many stages of our collective Covid reaction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: M.L.B. Moves in Players’ Direction, but Delays Seem Inevitable
description: The latest offer would raise minimum salaries and tweak the luxury tax system. But with pitchers and catchers scheduled to report this week, players remain underwhelmed.
content: For roughly an hour on Saturday, the lead negotiators and lawyers from Major League Baseball and the players’ union met at the league’s office in Manhattan. A few owners and players joined virtually. It was the fifth time since M.L.B. locked the players out on Dec. 2 that the sides had met about the major economic hurdles to a new labor deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: ‘We’re All Sort of Primed for Addiction’
description: The other public health crisis we’re living through right now.
content: Last August, I had a conversation with an old friend that I couldn’t stop thinking about. I have known Trevor Henderson for over a decade. Until recently, he was the director of the Nashville Metro Health Department’s overdose response program, which works with emergency medical workers and the community at large to reduce drug overdoses. With kind eyes and a rich Northern Irish brogue, Trevor speaks with the hard-won wisdom of those who’ve walked with suffering people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy and Melissa Hoppert
title: C.J. Uzomah wants to bathe in Skyline Chili, hold the spaghetti. The hype, explained.
description: A Cincinnati chili with a loyal cult following is getting nationwide attention with the Bengals in the Super Bowl.
content: Cincinnati Bengals tight end C.J. Uzomah said he would celebrate a Bengals win by bathing in Skyline Chili. “You put it in a swimming pool, and I’ll dive in there and eat my way out,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing: Fears of Invasion Mount
description: Airlines suspend flights over Ukraine.
content: Diplomacy is stalling and U.S. officials believe an invasion could begin at any time. Here are live updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sonia Shah, Jack D'Isidoro, Aaron Esposito, John Woo and Marion Lozano
title: The Sunday Read: ‘Animals That Infect Humans Are Scary. It’s Worse When We Infect Them Back’
description: Mink farms threaten to become a source of new coronavirus variants — and an object lesson in how “spillback” can make deadly diseases even deadlier.
content: There’s a working theory for the origins of Covid-19. It goes like this: Somewhere in an open-air market in Wuhan, China, a new coronavirus, growing inside an animal, first made the jump to a human. But what happens when diseases spread in the other direction?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum, Safiullah Padshah and Taimoor Shah
title: Biden’s Decision on Frozen Funds Stokes Anger Among Afghans
description: “It is a cruel act and a betrayal,” one shopkeeper said of the White House’s move, which could effectively bankrupt the Afghan central bank.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Many Afghans said they were outraged by the Biden administration’s decision to divert billions in frozen assets from the Afghan central bank to American families of 9/11 victims, as Afghanistan hurtles deeper into economic catastrophe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: Germany has swept the sliding sports so far: six events, six golds.
description: The country’s winning streak may end on Monday, however, with the women’s monobob race.
content: On their backs or on their bellies, by themselves or in pairs, competing in a relay — it has not mattered for Germany.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Here’s how to watch ice dancing (during and after the Super Bowl).
description: Or if you’re really enterprising, you can watch both.
content: The French team of Gabriella Papadakis and Guillaume Cizeron entered the Olympic ice dancing competition as the heavy favorite for gold, and they did not disappoint in the rhythm dance on Saturday. Now they will look to follow up on that performance, which has them in first place heading into the final day of competition in Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esha Ray
title: New Covid data show New York returning to pre-Omicron surge levels.
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul reported the lowest number of hospitalizations since mid-December.
content: As public health officials and others debate the moves of several Democratic governors this week to relax pandemic restrictions, new coronavirus data released on Saturday for New York show just how far the state has come from its most recent peak in January, when daily new infections and hospitalizations were alarmingly high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: U.S. prime-time broadcast coverage includes freestyle skiing, ice dancing and monobob.
description: Eileen Gu hits the snow for slopestyle qualifiers, while medals are up for grabs in the monobob and ice dancing finals.
content: The U.S. broadcast coverage of the 2022 Winter Games continues with qualifiers in slopestyle. Gold medals are on the line in ice dancing and monobob. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: Inside McConnell’s Campaign to Take Back the Senate and Thwart Trump
description: Senator Mitch McConnell is working furiously to bring allies to Washington who will buck Donald J. Trump. It’s not going according to plan.
content: PHOENIX — For more than a year, former President Donald Trump has berated Gov. Doug Ducey of Arizona, savaging him for refusing to overturn the state’s presidential results and vowing to oppose him should he run for the Senate this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: A Rising Death Toll
description: Overdoses are increasing at a troubling rate.
content: Drug overdoses now kill more than 100,000 Americans a year — more than vehicle crash and gun deaths combined.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Bennett
title: What Happens When a Striving Ingénue Gets Mixed Up With an Older Man?
description: Imogen Crimp’s debut novel, “A Very Nice Girl,” is a reminder of the dangers of caring too much about what other people think.
content: A VERY NICE GIRLBy Imogen Crimp
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: After rough first run, Eileen Gu qualifies for slopestyle.
description: The 18-year-old who grew up in California but competes for China already has one gold medal in big air.
content: The Eileen Gu Show moved to the mountains, as China’s new favorite Olympic athlete — an 18-year-old freestyle skier from California — began competing in the second of her three events.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Once a Youth Football Mecca, L.A. Now Struggles to Find Kids Who’ll Play
description: Demographic changes and parents’ reservations made the game less popular among children in Los Angeles. But with help from the Rams and the Chargers, football is making a modest comeback.
content: Follow along with our live coverage of the 2022 Super Bowl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Dwayne Johnson gets the crowd energized.
description: The actor took to the field right before kickoff.
content: Just before kickoff, the actor Dwayne Johnson tapped into his wrestling background to pump up the crowd on the field at SoFi Stadium. Wearing a maroon outfit, with his muscles popping out the shirt, Johnson, nicknamed, “The Rock” because of his bulky physique, screamed into the microphone to create excitement. Though the game is in Southern California, the fan support is leaning toward the Bengals with a bunch of orange jerseys peppered in the stands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Carlotta Gall
title: Unpaid and Potentially Stateless, Afghan Diplomats Seek Permission to Remain in U.S.
description: American banks have suspended government accounts to prevent the Taliban from gaining access to funds, suspending the salaries of many workers.
content: WASHINGTON — Already reeling from a Taliban takeover of their government and a humanitarian disaster in their homeland, Afghan diplomats in the United States are grappling with another bleak reality: the loss of pay and the possibility of being deported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas
title: On the Scene at SoFi Stadium
description: It’s 82 degrees and sunny on Super Bowl Sunday in L.A., and the scene around SoFi Stadium is like a summer block party.
content: It’s 82 degrees and sunny on Super Bowl Sunday in L.A., and the scene around SoFi Stadium is like a summer block party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oskar Garcia
title: The Sports Betting Bowl
description: As legalized sports betting expands to more states, Super Bowl LVI is expected to be the biggest wagering day in history.
content: As legalized sports betting expands to more states, Super Bowl LVI is expected to be the biggest wagering day in history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Network Pool
title: Blinken Denounces North Korea’s Recent Missile Tests
description: Alongside his counterparts from South Korea and Japan, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken condemned the North’s recent ballistic missile launches while also calling for a resumption of talks with Pyongyang.
content: Alongside his counterparts from South Korea and Japan, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken condemned the North’s recent ballistic missile launches while also calling for a resumption of talks with Pyongyang.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters, Storyful and The Associated Press
title: Canadian Police Arrest Protesters Blocking Vital Bridge
description: The police in Windsor, Ontario, made arrests and towed pickup trucks, clearing a road to a key border crossing to the United States. The authorities said the bridge would reopen once conditions were deemed safe.
content: The police in Windsor, Ontario, made arrests and towed pickup trucks, clearing a road to a key border crossing to the United States. The authorities said the bridge would reopen once conditions were deemed safe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joel Stein
title: How Did Squarespace Know Podcasts Would Get This Big?
description: From “This Week in Tech” to Zendaya at the Super Bowl.
content: In 2009, Anthony Casalena was listening to a lot of podcasts, especially one called “This Week in Tech,” a round table where tech reporters gathered to talk about things like Farmville, Foursquare and the iFart app.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: ‘Alt-Right Armory’ Podcaster Faces Charges of Possessing Machine Guns
description: The podcaster, Joseph Paul Berger, and his father, Joseph Raymond Berger, had 13 fully automatic machine guns and 12 gun silencers that were illegally imported into the United States, officials said.
content: A Pennsylvania man who hosted what he described as “the alt-right’s favorite firearms-related podcast” was, along with his father, indicted on several gun charges, including possessing machine guns and unregistered silencers, according to federal prosecutors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: It’s time for Super Bowl recipes, whether you watch the game or not: carne asada, nachos and more.
content: Good morning. It’s Super Bowl Sunday for a lot of Americans, even for those who have no intention of watching the Rams play the Bengals this evening. It’s a chance to make a carne asada that tastes of Los Angeles or Cincinnati chili, to devour chicken wings, nachos, guacamole and queso in advance of the advertising, the violence or just a quiet night reading Sheila Heti on the couch. I hope you’ll join us. We have plenty of recipes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Success Story, but Also a Myth?
description: Readers respond to an essay by Tara Westover, the author of “Educated,” about college education and the American dream.

title: Corrections: Feb. 13, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Feb. 13, 2022.
content: An article last Sunday about the wedding of Beatriz Rivera and Edgar Alonzo misspelled the surname of the owner of Acme Bar & Company. She is Jennifer Seidman, not Sied­man.
source.name: The New York Times
